reviewText:
Dawn of War continues its epic conquest with Winter Assault. Fixing most of the unbalances of the original. Winter Assault even brings an additional kick by adding the Imperial Guard (my favorite team).

Story:
The campaign offers two stories, the Forces of Order and the Campaign of Disorder. The Forces of Order has five missions and that switches between the Eldar and Imperial Guard. Unlike your traditional strategy campaign both the campaigns allow you to manipulate the story. On the fourth mission you can change the campaign by deciding which team makes it too the end. This is similar for the Campaign of Disorder, where you play as the Orcs and Chaos Marines. The campaign is rather fun and delves into the issue of the fallen Imperator Class Imperial Titan. If you played 40,000k Space Marine you know have seen the Titan before and that it is known as a ultimate weapon. Each team has a different objective, but they all revolve around getting to the same final location. Interestingly, there are four endings there is one “correct” ending which the story picks up and continues with in Dark Crusade (do not read the next secion if you do not want any clues to the games campaign) the Eldar Ending. In the next game Dark Crusade" the story continues where the Eldar left off
date:
this is not obvious but notable from how the games dynamic is set up in the strategic map campaign.

Additions:
The new team is the Imperial Guard. If you are unfamiliar with the series they essentially represent
hoursPlayed: a futuristic style army based around communist Russia. The army is initially based on sheer numbers and they even have units which execute soldiers in order to scare other units and make them hold the line. The game shows the Imperial Guardsmen surrounded by snow
voteText: which as we know is a strong environmental factor in Russia. Thus this team to me is like playing as the Russians. Similar to the orcs they fight in numbers
helpfulPercent:
but unlike the orcs the strategies for the Imperial Guard early in the game lies in pairing up squads appropriately with commander units and working with your hero squad. While later the Imperial guard shift and play like other teams by using a few strong unit squads rather than keeping the weaker Imperial Guardsmen.

Multiplayer:
If you want to play online with friends I would recommend getting Dawn of War: Dark Crusade instead. As Dark Crusade fixes most of the glitches and unbalances of Dawn of War Winter Assault. These are not really game-breaking
votesHelpful:
but can be noticeable. Plus Dark Crusade offers the benefit of adding two new teams. One of which is featured in the Winter Assault campaign.

If you haven’t played the first Dawn of War then skip the next section:
My major gripe about this game is that the story of Gabriel Angelos is not continued. Luckily for all those wondering the story of Gabriel Angelos and the reviving the Daemon of Khorne is covered in Dawn of War II: Retribution.

Results:
I loved this game and all the installments so much I repurchased them all on steam. Despite that I still have all the discs
votesFunny: right next to me. Although it looks like there are more Pros than Cons this game is a good game
commentsCount:
and definitely a worthy installment to the epic Dawn of War saga.

Pros:
+More balanced than the first game
+Campaign introduces new elements to the story by allowing you to choose the ending.
+A whole new team (the Imperial Guard)
+Missions are rather interesting and the campaign is not too long.
+Economic
column17:
and macro unit management
+Fantastic story and campaign (which is very rare in a strategy game)
+Amazing teams which each play completely differently.
+Fast paced gameplay which requires expansion to acquire resource nodes (but those nodes do not run out like in most games)
+Unit customization allows you to create squads for specific tasks
+Fantastic computer AI that puts you to your wits

Cons:
-My game glitched after the third mission of the Campaign of Disorder where I could not load any of my saves (I tried validating the files and it replaced the lost files yet still I could not load any of my saves. Then I tried to reinstall the game
column18: but still to no avail).\n-The third mission for the Campaign of Disorder is rather cumbersome as you have to retrieve Imperial Guardsmen from one side of the map to the other. This would be fine if there was something along the way to keep you occupied
column19: but reality is by the time you've got to this step the map is already baron as you killed everything else.\n-The game can still not be played with a second monitor. If you have two monitors and you move the cursor to the edge of your monitor that is adjacent to your extended monitor then the cursor leaves the game and causes it to minimize. It’s as if the game is permanently in windowed mode.\n-The movement AI can be annoying causing units to spread out rather than clump together. This is fine expect when you want to ambush an enemy and one unit gets too close because it decided to go too far from the rest of the group."

reviewText: The Winter Assault expansion is a great addition to Warhammer: 40,000: Dawn of War.  The dual campaign allows players to take the role of either Order or Chaos and fight on either side of the war taking place with a fully fleshed out story.  If this alone wasn't enough, you also have the option toward the end of each campaign of furthering the goals of one of the two factions inside of your original choice.  As such, there are four endings to the campaign available.\n\nFor the most part, it's more of the same of the original Dawn of War that most of us seem to have loved.  If you enjoyed the vanilla game, it's definitely worth picking up.

reviewText: An expansion pack to the original Dawn Of War, this features many races to play as. There are two campaigns, the Forces Of Order and the Campaign Of Disorder. The gameplay rules are pretty much the same as the first DoW, and as the title says, you are always facing down winter in the different snow capped battlefields you fight on. Players who want to know the full story of the DoW series in order should play this after they play the original DoW, because what happens in this version connects with other games in the DoW series (not telling which one, you have to find out yourself!). Good game.

reviewText: Dawn Of War Winter Assault is the first addition to the Dawn Of War series, this being so, it is a little rough around the edges, but as the first Dawn Of War game was great, this one is good aswell. I will admit this is probably my least favorite of all the Dawn Of War games. I cant really put my finger on why this is so, it just is. That being said though Winter Assault is still a pretty great entry in the series, You will have many hours of campaign play, with multiple factions and endings as well as fun multiplayer (if you have someone to play). If you are looking for an RTS series or are just a fan of Warhammer 40k, I have got to say I recommend the Dawn Of War series!

reviewText: This expansion was ok for quick fun but the briefness of each campaign left me wishing for more. I thought the Imperial Guard were easily the most interesting (I wish they'd had an entire game), while the Eldar were borderline boring. Recommended if you're looking for quick fun and enjoy WH40K ...but not a must play.

reviewText:
The armies of Order and Disorder have descended on the frozen planet of Lorn V. A World Class Titan was found buried in the ice and the armies of men and horrors of Chaos scramble to get their hands on it. The stage is set for the Winter Assault of Lorn V.

The first expansion of the first Dawn of War adds the Imperial Guardsmen as a playable faction. The Guard sets itself apart with massive disposable numbers and cheap buildings, set off against strong armour units and many special leader units. It is a special mix that requires a new and vastly different approach to master.

The expansion comes with two seperate campaigns. One where you play as the forces of Order, to protect the planet and to keep the titan from falling in the hands of Chaos. While on the other side you can play as the Orcs and forces of Chaos to claim this weapon to rule the universe. The campaigns are entertaining and change up the formula just enough to keep the interesting, but it does suffer from occasional jumps in difficulty that can ruin your fun severely.

As with the original, the expansive multiplayer mode is still in place with all the modes availible to whoever seeks to indulge him/herself in this field, but with Dark Crusade and Soulstorm widely availible it seems futile to linger in this slightly dated expansion. Still, the campaign merits a run, if just for the hilarious antics of Orcs and Chaos.

reviewText:
The first expansion pack released for WH40K Dawn of War 1 that was developed by Relic Entertainment in 2005, Winter Assault adds on to what made the core game successful to start with with two new campaigns and a new faction from the Imperium of Man:  The mass infantry-throwing, artillery-heavy Imperial Guard.

-Story:  Taking place during/after the last game on the iceball of a planet called Lorne V, the player is tasked with aiding General Sturn and his regiment of Imperial Guardsman reclaim a Warlord Titan:  A giant mecha spawned of forgotten technology that the Imperium hopes to recover and mass produce in their war against their enemies (read:  Everyone not Imperium).  The task proves much more difficult than it sounds, as war-loving orks and blood-thirsty forces of chaos stand in the way.  For the first time in its day, Winter Assault allows the player to choose between two separate campaigns, where they choose to play as the forces of order (Imperial Guard and Eldar) or the forces of disorder (Chaos and Orks).  Unlike most games where alliances remain permanent however, players can (or should I say, are forced to) determine which of these sides ultimately win because in Warhammer 40K there is no peace, there is only war.  Unlike the first game in Dawn of War I, there are multiple endings (4 actually) that depend on the player's choices.  Great for adding a bit of replay value, and while the story isn't spectacular, it's not bad by any means.  Score: 4/5

-Gameplay:  Nothing much has changed between Dawn of War and Winter Assault, save for the addition of new maps and a new faction in its entirety:  The Imperial Guard.  While the Imperial Guard had some units featured in the first game's campaign, Winter Assault focuses greatly adds upon them by granting the Imperial Guard faction a vast increase in infantry units and artillery, with the most noteable addition being the powerful, bullet-soaking brick of a tank called the Baneblade.  The fact that the Imperial Guard infantry can travel between their buildings adds for some new tactics, combined with their additional units all help flesh out the faction.  Despite its focus on the IG, none of the other factions are completely left out, as they each gain additional units, some with new abilities to mix things up a bit.  It might not seem like a lot of additions, but for the casual and dedicated WH40K fan it's enough to keep things interesting.  Score: 4/5

-Graphics:  Because Winter Assault and Dawn of War were built from the same engine, not much has been done with graphical improvements.  This isn't a bad thing however, as consistency is something to expect in any expansion pack or DLC.  The frigid atmosphere of Lorne V further adds to the sense of bleakness that the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40K is known for, as it creates the impression that even the weather is out to kill you.  The ice and snow also creates an interesting contrast to draw more attention to the scorch marks, blood stains, and general scenes of death and destruction that make WH40K what it is.  So while there might nto be anything new, the old adage If it isn't broken
date: don't fix it" works in this case.  Score:  4.25/5\n\n-Sound:  While Winter Assault recycles many of the same tracks and sound effects from Dawn of War
recommended: it does add new music and lines.  The masculine choir added to the orchestral soundtrack fits both the mood of the Imperial Guard and the frozen environment they're in
hoursPlayed: and some of the lines delivered by the commanders of each faction are pretty memorable.   Much like the situation with the graphics
voteText: there wasn't a lot added to the sound aspect of the game
helpfulPercent: but what was added works very well.  Score:  4.25/5\n\n-Replayability:  As said earlier
votesHelpful: the fact that Winter Assault features two campaigns with a total of four different possible endings adds to the replay value of this game.  The maps from the original Dawn of War are also included in the multiplayer aspect of the game
votesTotal: and the Imperial Guard faction offers a new challenge for those looking to try a different faction in multiplayer.  While Winter Assault's multiplayer might have seen some form of population back in its heyday
votesFunny: online matches are practically unheard of save for games between friends.  Still
commentsCount: the amount of replayability for this game in comparison to is predecessor is an improvement
column16: albeit a marginal one.  Score:  3.75/5\n\n-Overall:  Winter Assault is a worthy continuation of the Dawn of War games with some worthwhile new content.  With subtle changes to the game's mechanics and more than one campaign
column17: Relic Entertainment adds enough to satisfy most fans while avoiding any major changes.  Those expecting a massive amount of additions will be somewhat underwhelmed
column19: I'd recommend getting this game during a sale if you need something to pass the time
column20: it's worth it.  Overall Score: 20.25/25 or  81%"

reviewText:
TL;DR:
Winter Assault is a passable expansion to a great game. It adds some unique experiences and mechanics to the gameplay and forces players to try out the different armies available, adding some variety to the single-player campaign. The massive difficulty spikes add some excitement and challenge to the experience, but some frustration as well. Unfortunately, even though the total number of missions across the two campaigns is the same as it was in the original Dawn of War, Winter Assault's single-player game feels short by comparison. All in all, I didn't love it, but I still had fun and it was still worth playing.

Read the Full review here: http://dagondogs.com/2016/01/20/dawn-of-war-winter-assault-review/

reviewText:
If you've played Dawn of War 1 then you're basically paying for one more added faction and an extra unit for every other faction. And this is a good thing because the campaign is better than ever with multiple choices and you get to play as both order/disorder fighting for a powerful artifact throughout the story.

Much of the game is still the same as the original except you'll be getting used to the mob tactics backed up by powerful armour of the Imperial Guard along with all their secondary commanders such as commissars, priests and psykers all with a unique ability that help all the small meatshield soldiers push through almost any obstacle. Personally my most favourite faction to play as out the rest and all their units are very well voice acted.

If you're wanting to get this game to play as the Imperial Guard or other factions though to test out their new units, move along and grab Dark Crusade or Soulstorm instead. This game does bring in a few new things but nothing to really jump out the chair for but if you love the games for their campaign then this is worth the money.

reviewText:
I normally would not write a review for something I did not finish, but since I ragequit this nonsense expansion I suppose I feel the need to say why I think it sucks.

Quite simply, it is horribly unbalanced. I got most of the way through the Order campaign, and the second-to-last level is just asinine. You actually get a choice of which faction to side with--which changes the objective significantly--but both options are terrible. Stick with your lovable, underdog human scamps, and you are rewarded with an escort mission through hell. You get a toolbag space marine commander who whines about how it is taking you too long to slaughter an entire Ork army with your dozen or so militia guys, and the fighting is just incessant.

After failing a half dozen times because the onslaught provided no breaks, I opted to try and see what my unfriendly neighborhood aliens were up to. On a funny note, the PC controlled faction of my beloved guardsmen were wiped out equally as fast as I was, so I felt a little better about that. Anyway, this was the first time I spent significant time with the aliens, and while they look cool and have fancy weapons, it feels like I would be better off throwing urine-soaked snowballs at the endless legions. As a bonus, the enemy would just roll through my guys (who had such pathetic firepower they could not even stop 1 enemy as they passed by) to directly attack my base.

I suffered through about an hour of that. I built up a pretty large nerf-wielding army, and relocated my base twice (as instructed), only to be hit nonstop bombardment on one side, and a somehow endless-er army on the other. I probably could have pushed through it to win at some point, but what's the point?

I get it, war is hell. It's relentless, it's unforgiving, and you're not supposed to enjoy it.

All things I specifically do not look for in a game. Again, I am sure I could have slogged through it eventually, but why bother? Maybe some people find ridiculously unfair fights to be fun, but I'll pass on that.

reviewText:
Ok i just came from classic dow and the main difference iv seen is that there is a change from hard counters to soft counters which has changed up the game completely it changes the game a lot.  The standard 1v1 games that would result in a mass infantry battle in classic to more of a tech game in wa which allow more use/variety of all units choices at use and wa made the change to anti vehicle unit type haveing the own individual counter example(horrors/fire dragons) makeing life alot simpler but giveing the unit type a individual role. Imperial guard were a good adition to the game whcih added much to the game adding new units/building and style of play giveing a player that like to turtle or play defenceive and liked to use vehicles a race to play.The AI current on steam  was  was quite challengeing on insane it does cheat but knows how to change its unit choices and  always keeps the same eco always and haveing more troops then i did so it gave me a challenge in learning to be able to beat it if i what'd to play something more fair i could always just lower the difficulty. As it quite difficult/expensive/complicated to build an advanced ai that can do many example builds/tactic/micro was not bad in my oppinion.My only drawbacks was with the campaign did not tie into the classic campaign as i would have liked it left my questions unanswered and was not as fun. it need to be worked on more still for its time when this game was realeased it was decent but its not something i what to play over and over again as it was not that interesting. More maps is always good adding some more stratigic map and colourful maps with more objects so they do look quite interesting and change up the game a  bit.

-multiplayer i give 7/10 i could have spent more time on it if there were players.
-single player a average 5/10 not as great as the predecessor.

reviewText: Dawn of War Winter Assault adds in 2 new races you get to play as from the Dawn of War franchise. The campaigns are very linear and scripted so not sure if campaign mode is good for you. reviewText:
This game is a lot like the original Dawn of War in terms of gameplay. However the campaign is awful. It's only five missions long. You can play as Order (Imperial Guard and Eldar) or Disorder (Orcs and Chaos).

Order campaign has a bunch of sections where you control an Imperial Guard base. I personally hate Imperial Guard. They seem really underpowered and weak. And the Eldar parts are basically hero missions.

Disorder campaign has a really annoying 3rd mission.

Both campaigns are essentially the same story/content wise with only some differences which I mentioned. Both sides have a really confusing 4th mission where you have to switch back and forth between the two races. The transition is very choppy and annoying.

reviewText: I rate Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War: Winter Assualt 2/5. Bad.\n\nWhile the multiplayer aspect of this game is pretty much the same as in any other Dawn of War game (except this add-on appears to be the first to have allowed you to play as the Imperial Guard, which is a nice, though not entirely well done addition) the single player campaigns (there are 2, each of which have 2 different endings depending on which individual faction you decide you support the most) are not well done at all. The single player campaigns do not play much like normal skirmish matches but instead require you to complete very specific objectives. This would be all well and good were it not for the fact that, (at least in the good-guy's Order" campaign I tried to play) the campaign (and your units) are hampered by bugs and design mistakes which make the whole experience enormously frustrating. Too frustrating for me to want to complete anyhow
date: not when there are so many other
recommended:
clearly better games out there.

Good things:
+There are 2 single player campaigns
hoursPlayed:
each of which feature 2 factions resulting in a grand total of 4 possible endings.

Middling things:
+/-You can play as the Imperial Guard (but you can also do that more effectively in the Dark Crusade add-on). The numbers of imperial guard units which you control is still not numerous enough to be canonical. The battles still don't feel extremely epic (despite the nice ambient battle sounds in some missions). In the overarching context of Warhammer 40k seems very
voteText: very strange to be able to simply teleport in replacement imperial guardsmen as squads become depleted (and this also feels strange for most other factions as well). Why not just teleport everyone who's available all at once and flood the battlefield with soldiers like the Imperial Guard would actually want to do?\n+/- Which ending you get apparently depends on a particular choice you make toward the end of teach campaign and which campaign you chose from the outset.\n+/- The graphics
votesTotal:
the same quality as in the original Dawn of War Game.

Bad Things:
-You usually have to build up the numbers of your force during the course of each battle. This is yet another game which resorts to the tired and true (and completely unrealistic) Command and Conquer styled game mechanic of getting buildings
votesFunny: building the force and attacking with what you've built. I'm honestly getting truly sick of seeing this completely unrealistic game mechanic. All RTS games do not need to be this way but most of them are exactly this way and usually implement it in a manner which makes little sense (as we see here in Winter Assault). If the imperial Guard is really so massive they should be able to bring their own pre-built tanks and such along with them (etc.) and they should have already landed a whole bunch of them during the initial planetary invasion (and the same is true for most other factions) Only the Eldar and the Necrons
column16: should be using the "build-your-army" mechanic that all factions must use in these games
column17: and even then that side of things should be handled automatically for the most part.\n-Units will automatically engage enemy units whenever they are in range. Once engaged units will absolutely refuse to retreat or tactically withdraw even if they are engaged against a clearly stronger force. Given the manner in which the main campaign missions of winter Assault are setup
column18: where you continually have fewer forces than your enemies
column19: this (bug? oversight? design error?) problem causes the game to become severely (and needlessly) frustrating. The elite units of the Eldar should be disciplined enough to withdraw when ordered. The non-elite Imperial Guard units should actively run away from such confrontations (unless a commissar is present) but your imperial Guard (being the elite Cadians I guess) will never
column20: ever run away even when they clearly should do so and (unlike the cadians) will ignore any orders to do so. This frustrating problem effectively breaks the game for me
column21: particularly when there are so many other
column22: better games out there to play.\n-The space marines still look cute and cuddly."

reviewText:
Played through the tutorial on a 'free weekend'.
Looks like a nice game, reminds me of Command & Conquer Generals.

Unfortunately two issues with the game will stop me from purchasing it.
1) Game will not start if I choose high detail settings plus large resolution fullscreen.
Therefore forced to play it in an 800x600 window.
2) Game will not start if I choose high quality sound settings.
Therefore forced to use low quality sound settings.

Other users have posted about these problems in the discussion forums.
These should be easy bugs to fix, why they are still in this released game is strange.

Pros:
+ Solid storyline
+ Four different endings
+ Bug-free
+ Classic RTS Gameplay
+ Several different, balanced factions
+ Great multiplayer/matchmaking
+ Adds the Imperial Guard as a playable race!

Cons:
- Game is a bit short; single-player campaign lasts roughly 20 hours
- Campaign gets repetitive; multiple endings require playing the same maps over and over again

Overall: The first expansion to the Dawn of War game.  It introduces a new playable race, and gives a more branching storyline.  The RTS gameplay is still great, and all the factions are still balanced against one another.  It's still the same game at its core, and the imperial guard are a blast to play if you like tanks... and who doesn't like tanks?

Bottom Line: If you liked Dawn of War, you'll like this game.  By itself, it's still a solid RTS worth playing.

Expansion to the original Dawn of War (I) Title which offers one new Race, the Imperial Guard, which offers more variety in Multiplayer Skirmishes. Small fine-tuning adjustments to gameplay. Campaign innovated from a single linear Story to Two juxta-posed Campaigns - Order & Disorder, with the player controlling the Races ajacent to each supposed moral standing. Best experienced when having the previous Dawn Of War (I) title to maximize Multiplayer capability (allows players to use races introduced to the original Title).

This is kind of a mixed bag. Is it worth it? I found the single player campaign to be quite unbalanced (hard even on normal) but the new units for multiplayer make it worth it. If you don't mind trying and re-trying missions a few times--give it a go.
Have fun holding the line.

One of the best RTS's I've played (i've played more hours than shown as got this before steam as well).

Loads of armies and units, all of which look amazing. Great voice acting etc. Great bang for buck and always on sale.

Just get it.
cool

Man, they really hammed it up for this game. Sometimes, it was the right kind of over the top, such as the voice acting.

Other times, it was pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, like the cliche mission objectives. It's not a good expansion but it eeks out a recommendation for those looking for a disposable RTS fix.

You'll have a much better time if you can guess what the level designer intended you to do.

it's a great expansion pack to an already great game. (;

The story mode is quite enjoyable pitting the Imperial Guard, Space Marines (just a little bit) and Eldar against the Orks and and the forces of Chaos. The story mode is split into 2 main segments, one focusing on the Imperial Guard and Eldar, the other being focused on the Orks and Chaos. The second to last missions have two endings each. Depending on what faction is used to win the second to last mission sets who is going to be used for the last mission (This can be altered by loading up the second to last missions and using the other factions. The missions are quite long and sometimes require the use of many different tactics to complete. The last mission itself is enjoyable for another reason that I will not spoil.

This expansion added a few new units to the game outside of the Imperial guard e.g. Chaplains for the Space Marines.
And of course there is the new faction, the Imperial Guard. The IG are weak as infantry, requiring large amounts to be effective, but do have the balancing of their forces by having a very strong set of vehicles. They utilise the Basilisk (the only real long range unit in the game), The Leman Russ (A fairly strong main battle tank) and a few others. All of the units in the Imperial Guard are completely overshadowed by its magnum opus, the Baneblade. The Baneblade is the most powerful unit in the entire game with its ridiculously high health and major firepower. The Baneblade is the only unit that can easily go toe-to-toe with an entire army, take out there base and then return home without taking too much damage.

Although all the units are available in the later expansion (that do not require the original game or any other expansions, I would recommend buying this expansion aswell, even if it is just for the story mode.

This game is cool. I have passed the campaign in 5.5h of gaming.

I will do some pros and cons for this game.

PROS
-This game has some minor bugs but nothing to be scared of, no crashes with the game whatsoever
-Graphics are good
-Lots of models for army
-The soundtracks are awesome too
-The Singleplayer is breath-taking, planning every move, every second on the battlefield
-The game has 2 campaigns, Order and Disorder. I have played Disorder for 5.5h(I don't plan to play Order in near future but I will play it sometime in the future)
-2 new armies are added to the arsenal(but you can play only one of them)
-The game is not forgotten but it needs no updates

CONS
-The textures for models are somehow messed up and all the colors are smudged(not the whole model, but a part of it)
-The community is almost dead
-The Multiplayer is almost dead, went three times to find matches but there were 2 people in the Lobby and they were probably Idle

I rate it 8/10. I recommend it. Would shout BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD again!
